data: Rectangular shape, now broken into four fragments. Heavily corroded.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Partially reopened following extensive restoration work. Comprehensive collection of archaeological material, predominantly from the West of the island, with an important Etruscan collection.
Centre of Palermo, Piazza Olivella 24, 90100 - Palermo
Il Santuario della Malophoros a Selinunte
E. Gabrici, «Il Santuario della Malophoros a Selinunte», Monumenti Antichi 32 (1927): 5–419
Further comments on archaic Greek inscriptions
L.H. Jeffery, ‘Further Comments on Archaic Greek Inscriptions’, Annual of the British School at Athens 50 (1955): 67–84
Margherita Guarducci, Epigrafia greca, 4 voll. (Rome: Istituto Poligrafico dello Stato, Libreria dello Stato, 1967)
Iscrizioni greche arcaiche di Sicilia e Magna Grecia. Iscrizioni di Sicilia. I. Megara e Selinunte
Renato Arena, Iscrizioni greche arcaiche di Sicilia e Magna Grecia. Iscrizioni di Sicilia. I. Megara e Selinunte, 1st ed., vol. 1 (Milano: Istituto Editoriale Cisalpino - La Goliardica, 1989)
Inscriptions grecques dialectales de Sicile : contribution à l'étude du vocabulaire grec colonial
Laurent Dubois, Inscriptions grecques dialectales de Sicile : contribution à l’étude du vocabulaire grec colonial, CEFR 119 (Rome: Ecole française de Rome, 1989)
Las tabellae defixionis de la Sicilia griega
M. A. López Jimeno, Las tabellae defixionis de la Sicilia griega (Amsterdam, 1991)
Corpus delle defixiones di Selinunte: edizione e commento
L. Bettarini, Corpus delle defixiones di Selinunte: edizione e commento, Hellenica (Alessandria: Edizioni dell’Orso, 2005)
A survey of Greek defixiones not included in the special corpora
D.R. Jordan, ‘A Survey of Greek Defixiones Not Included in the Special Corpora’, Greek, Roman and Byzantine Studies 26 (1985): 151–97
J. B. Curbera, «Defixiones», in Sicilia epigraphica. Atti del convegno internazionale Erice 15-18 Ottobre 1998. (ASNP ser.iv, quad.1), a c. di M. I. Gulletta (Pisa, 1999), 159–86
Gabrici, 1927, Il Santuario della Malophoros a Selinunte
Jeffery, 1955, Further comments on archaic Greek inscriptions
Lopez-Jimeno, 1991, Las tabellae defixionis de la Sicilia griega
Bettarini, 2005, Corpus delle defixiones di Selinunte: edizione e commento

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Bettarini ;
  • 3: Ͱύ(ψις) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno
  • 4: Ͱεˉρακλ(είδας) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno
  • 5: Ͱιστία(ρχος) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno
  • 6: Χάρο(ψ/-πίδας/-πῖνος)Dubois, Lopez Jimeno
  • 7: Ͱύ(ψις) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno
  • 8: [Ἀ]μάρι(ος) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno
  • 12: Ͱιστί(αρχος) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno
  • 13: ἌϜισ(τος)Dubois, Lopez Jimeno; Ἆγις Arena
  • 15: Σάσα(μος) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno

English translation

Italian translation

commentary

This tablet is peculiar on account of its use of nominal abbreviations, which constitutes a rather unusual practice for curse tablets on account of the fact that they often required precision when indicating the victim to be cursed. If we accept ΑϜΙΣ in l.13, we must recall that in the Sicilian Greek dialects intervocalic digamma is unattested, even in the earliest inscriptions. For this reason, Lopez Jimeno dates the tablet to the fourth century BCE; Bettarini, however, believes that the author of the text is not a Sicilian but a mainland Greek speaker.

Text after Bettarini Ͱύ(ψις) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno Ͱεˉρακλ(είδας) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno Ͱιστία(ρχος) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno Χάρο(ψ/-πίδας/-πῖνος)Dubois, Lopez Jimeno Ͱύ(ψις) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno [Ἀ]μάρι(ος) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno Ͱιστί(αρχος) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno ἌϜισ(τος)Dubois, Lopez Jimeno; Ἆγις Arena Σάσα(μος) Dubois, Lopez Jimeno

This tablet is peculiar on account of its use of nominal abbreviations, which constitutes a rather unusual practice for curse tablets on account of the fact that they often required precision when indicating the victim to be cursed. If we accept ΑϜΙΣ in l.13, we must recall that in the Sicilian Greek dialects intervocalic digamma is unattested, even in the earliest inscriptions. For this reason, Lopez Jimeno dates the tablet to the fourth century BCE; Bettarini, however, believes that the author of the text is not a Sicilian but a mainland Greek speaker.
